The biofilm of probiotic bacteria often releases several bioactive compounds that benefit host physiology, including anti-inflammatory and immune-modulating properties. Biofilm by probiotic bacteria further enhances the therapeutic efficacy in various health conditions, including gastrointestinal disorders, immune dysfunction, and metabolic diseases.

Waterborne infections are a substantial hazard to public health, especially in areas with inadequate sanitation and water infrastructure. Bacterial biofilm is essential in mitigating waterborne disease by lowering microbial contamination in water distribution systems. For instance, biofilm produced on the inner surfaces of water pipes forms protective coatings that prevent pathogenic bacteria such as Escherichia coli and Legionella pneumophila from attaching and growing (Hemdan et al., 2020). Thus, bacterial biofilm ensures access to safe and clean drinking water, a key component of SDG 3, by maintaining water quality and preventing pathogenic bacteria from entering the distribution system. The removal of pollutants and pathogens from drinking water is improved by innovative water treatment systems that utilize biofilm-mediated mechanisms. Biofilm-based filtration devices, such as filters and biofilm reactors, use naturally occurring microbial communities to remove organic pollutants and suspended particles and eradicate pathogenic bacteria and viruses (Werkneh, 2022). For example, decentralized water treatment facilities have used biofilm reactors with specialized microbial consortia to treat faecal pathogen-contaminated surfaces and groundwater (Gomec, 2010). In resource-constrained environments, these biofilm-based technologies provide cost-effective and long-term solutions for improving water quality and reducing waterborne infections.

Airborne diseases, often transmitted through respiratory droplets and aerosols, pose significant health challenges. Bacterial biofilm plays a pivotal role in reducing the transmission of airborne pathogens such as Streptococcus pneumoniae, Streptococcus pyogenes, Klebsiella pneumonia, Mycoplasma pneumoniae, Haemophilus influenzae, and Mycobacterium tuberculosis by trapping and deactivating them in ventilation systems and indoor surfaces (Zhi et al., 2022). Bacterial biofilm formed on air filters and ventilation and air conditioning ducts capture airborne particles, including bacteria, viruses, and allergens, preventing their dissemination and reducing the risk of respiratory infections. Biofilm-mediated processes are often employed by developing air purification devices to eliminate airborne pollutants and enhance indoor air quality. The removal efficiency of airborne contaminants is increased by biofilm-coated filtration media, which include fibrous membranes and activated carbon filters (Zhang et al., 2022c). These materials offer surfaces for microbial colonization and biofilm development. Moreover, biofilm-coated air purifiers with ultraviolet germicidal irradiation (UVGI) have been used in hospitals to combat the spread of infectious diseases such as tuberculosis and influenza. Bacillus subtilis biofilm acts as a matrix that traps and degrades airborne pollutants, including VOCs, allergens, and pathogens, as they pass through the air purifier (Sahay and Wozniak, 2017). Similarly, Pseudomonas aeruginosa forms a robust biofilm that adheres to surfaces within air purifiers and traps various airborne particles (Marra et al., 2023). Thus, these biofilm-based air filtration devices provide an energy-efficient approach to improving respiratory health and reducing the spread of airborne diseases.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Biofilm-mediated wastewater remediation: clean water and sanitation (SDG 6)
ce:section.ce:para: Clean water and sanitation are fundamental human rights and critical components of sustainable development. However, wastewater pollution significantly threatens water quality and public health worldwide. According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), 780 million people are deprived of proper access to water sources, and 2.5 million lack improved sanitation. One out of four people is estimated to suffer from an acute freshwater shortage by 2050. The improper sanitation and contaminated wastewater result in the spread of various diseases like diarrhea, cholera, neglected tropical diseases, guinea worm disease, colitis, and trachoma (Jena et al., 2023). Thus, sanitation is vital to human health, and treating contaminated wastewater is the most predominant concern. For this reason, SDG 6 aims to ensure the availability and sustainable management of sewage and sanitation. Among various wastewater treatment methods, bacterial biofilm-mediated wastewater remediation offers a promising approach to address the challenges associated with wastewater pollution. Biofilm is crucial in removing organic and inorganic contaminants through physical, chemical, and biological processes in wastewater treatment. Several toxic heavy metals, including lead, cadmium, mercury, arsenic, and chromium, also contaminate the wastewater.

In the physical processes, bacterial biofilm provides a large surface area for adsorption and accumulating suspended solids and colloidal particles in wastewater. As water flows through biofilm reactors, particles are trapped within the biofilm matrix, facilitating their removal from the wastewater. Moreover, heavy metals are remediated from wastewater through different mechanisms such as bioaccumulation, bioprecipitation, biosorption, and biotransformation. In the chemical bioremediation process, biofilm-forming bacteria produce several enzymes and metabolites that facilitate the degradation and transformation of organic pollutants in wastewater (Haque et al., 2022b). These bacterial-mediated chemical reactions lead to the breakdown of complex organic compounds into simpler, less harmful substances, reducing the organic load and improving water quality. Aerobic and anaerobic biofilm-forming bacteria participate in various biological processes, including nitrification, denitrification, and phosphorus removal, contributing to nutrient removal and biodegradation of pollutants.

Bacterial biofilm produced by Pseudomonas aeruginosa and Bacillus subtilis degrades the organic pollutants, such as PAHs, in the wastewater (Ghorbannezhad et al., 2022). Moreover, this bacterial biofilm adheres to oil droplets in oil spills. It utilizes enzymes like hydroxylases and dioxygenases to break down complex hydrocarbons into simpler compounds that the bacteria can metabolize. Several bacteria, including Pseudomonas spp. and Bacillus subtilis, can degrade PAHs as a carbon and energy source (Kiamarsi et al., 2019). These bacteria produce enzymes, dioxygenases, and monooxygenases that break down PAH polymers into monomers, which the bacteria can then utilize for growth and metabolism. Biofilm-forming bacteria such as Shewanella spp. and Pseudomonas aeruginosa produce a biofilm that facilitates the reduction of toxic heavy metal ions, including cadmium, lead, mercury, chromium, and arsenic, to less toxic or insoluble forms (Syed et al., 2023). However, some bacterial biofilm promotes the biomineralization of heavy metal ions by precipitating them into insoluble metal sulfides, oxides, or carbonates.

The most promising approach for wastewater treatment is the development of bioreactors. The bioreactors offer several advantages, such as enhanced pollutant removal efficiency, reduced sludge production, shorter hydraulic retention times (HRT), and a high amount of active biomass. Thus, bacterial biofilm-mediated bioreactors have been extensively employed to purify heavily contaminated wastewater. Membrane biofilm reactors (MBRs) are involved in wastewater treatment, integrating the bacterial biofilm processes with membrane filtration technology to remove contaminants from wastewater efficiently. MBRs utilize biofilm-forming bacteria, including Pseudomonas spp., Bacillus spp., Nitrosomonas spp., Nitrobacter spp., and Acinetobacter spp., that produced on the surface of a semi-permeable membrane (Moloantoa et al., 2022). The biofilm provides a protective environment for bacterial growth and facilitates the degradation of organic matter, nutrients, and other harmful contaminants in the wastewater. The semi-permeable membrane in MBRs acts as a physical barrier that separates suspended solids with bacteria from the treated water. After treatment, the purified water eliminates harmful organic nutrients such as nitrogen, NH3, NO3 â and PO4 3â, along with a substantial decrease in BOD and COD (Hasan et al., 2021). The most recent implementation of a bioreactor is the MBBR plants, which are widely used for treating municipal and industrial wastewater. This approach combines the most beneficial features of activated sludge and biofiltration processes. All the processes, including aerobic, anoxic, and anaerobic processes, occur simultaneously within the reactor. The key feature of this method is the utilization of carriers that serve as substrates for biofilm growth, which move freely within the reactor. In aerobic processes, the movement of the carriers is propelled by gas agitation, while mechanical mixing ensures carrier mobility in anaerobic and anoxic processes. The use of mobile beds has the most advantageous effect in reducing congestion and enabling the utilization of the entire bioreactor volume (Zydney, 2016). Turbulence within the reactor, generated by shearing forces, facilitates proper compound diffusion with the bacterial biofilm while maintaining a thin biofilm layer. Additionally, this approach eliminates or reduces the need for biomass recirculation, which is a significant concern in the case of activated sludge systems and fixed bed biofilm (Waqas et al., 2020). In terms of energy consumption, the MBBR system with continuous aeration demanded a total energy requirement of 0.17â0.25 kWh/m3, whereas the conventional activated sludge (CAS) treatment process consumed energy ranging from 0.16 to 2.07 kWh/m3, as reported by different studies (Bodik and Kubaska, 2013; Dias et al., 2018; di Biase et al., 2019). Thus, bacterial biofilm-mediated wastewater remediation holds great promise for achieving SDG 6 following target 6a by providing sustainable solutions for clean treated water and proper sanitation for future generations.

Many developing countries have recently paid huge attention to clean water and sanitation. Moreover, increased community engagement in water supply and sanitation initiatives can improve outcomes. In India, nationwide sanitation campaigns such as Nirmal Bharat Abhiyan (Clean India CampaignâNBA), Total Sanitation Campaign (TSC), and Swachh Bharat Abhiyan (Clean India MissionâSBA) are conducted to ensure access to clean water (Routray et al., 2017). Similarly, the RAIN project, supported by the Coca-Cola company, aims to provide safe drinking water to the African population (Atuluku, 2022). Moreover, the Imo State Drinking Water Supply and Sanitation Project in Nigeria is a comparable initiative focused on improving water supply for the Nigerian population.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Biofuel sustainable energy production by bacterial biofilm: affordable clean energy (SDG 7)
ce:section.ce:para: Biofuel sustainable energy production through bacterial biofilm technology contributes significantly to achieving SDG 7. Bacterial biofilm offers a promising avenue for sustainable energy production due to their unique metabolic capabilities and ability to convert organic substrates efficiently into biofuels. The advantage of biofuel production using bacterial biofilm is their ability to utilize diverse feedstock, including agricultural residues, organic waste, and even wastewater, thus reducing reliance on finite fossil fuel resources (Gautam et al., 2022). This versatility enhances energy security and resilience while addressing environmental concerns associated with conventional energy sources. Moreover, biofuel production by bacterial biofilm promotes environmental sustainability by reducing greenhouse gas emissions and mitigating the impacts of climate change (Neogi et al., 2022). In addition, biofuel production through bacterial biofilm supports economic growth and social development by creating opportunities for decentralized energy production and rural development.

Bacterial biofilm has huge potential for generating renewable and inexhaustible biofuel and bioenergy. Various types of biofuels, including biodiesel, butanol, bioethanol, and biogas, can be produced from bacterial biomass. Recent advancements in research and technology have revealed that biofilm-mediated technology can significantly contribute to producing sustainable energy on a larger scale. Biofilm-forming bacterial fermentation of both liquid and solid biomass yields biogas, which can be used for transportation or generating power and heat (Wicker et al., 2023). Biofilm-forming bacteria such as Shewanella oneidensis MR-1 and Geobacter sulfurreducens MP can convert organic matter such as starch or sugar into useable electricity (Thapa et al., 2022). This underscores the potential of bacterial biofilm in generating cleaner and more sustainable electricity. The widespread adoption of this energy-saving technology is required for further research and development. Thus, biofuels have the potential to serve as a substantial energy source and can help to alleviate global fuel challenges. Biofilm-forming bacteria, mainly acid-tolerant bacteria, have the potential to produce bioelectricity.

A microbial fuel cell (MFC) represents a bioelectrochemical apparatus that converts energy into bioelectricity. Biofilm-forming bacteria expedite the breakdown of biodegradable compounds found in wastewater, generating bioelectricity (Mahto and Das, 2024). In an MFC, the bacteria are positioned within the anode chamber, where they initiate the oxidation process of both organic and inorganic substrates present in wastewater, producing CO2, protons, and electrons as byproducts (Jatoi et al., 2021). The protons generated at the anode travel towards the cathode through a proton exchange membrane, while the electrons are directed to the cathode via an external electrical circuit. Consequently, O2 is reduced at the cathode. Several biofilm-forming acid-tolerant bacteria, Acidithiobacillus sp. and Ferroplasma sp., can effectively act as bioelectrocatalysts under acidic conditions utilizing tetrathionate as an electron donor (Mallick and Das, 2023). Thus, biofuel sustainable energy production by bacterial biofilm technology represents a sustainable solution to achieve SDG 7 under target 7.1 while addressing interconnected environmental, social, and economic challenges. By harnessing the power of bacterial biofilm, we can accelerate the transition towards a more sustainable and resilient energy future.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Applications of bacterial biofilm in agricultural and industrial innovations: decent work and economic growth (SDG 8) and industry, innovation, and infrastructure (SDG 9)
ce:section.ce:para: Bacterial biofilm has wide applications in various agricultural and industrial sectors, driving advancements aligned with SDG 8 and SDG 9. SDG 8 aims to reduce unemployment rates, enhance labor efficiency, and foster economic expansion. It has been reported that labor productivity dropped to 2.812% from 2016 to 2021, reflecting global economic challenges and widespread underpayment of workers worldwide (Kanbur, 2021). The unemployment rate was 5.1%. The central objective of SDG 8 revolves around generating employment opportunities for vulnerable groups such as women, rural inhabitants, and individuals with low incomes or lacking employment in urban areas.

This bacterial biofilm is pivotal in enhancing productivity, promoting sustainability, and fostering innovation in various economic sectors. In agriculture, bacterial biofilm contributes to plant growth promotion, nutrient cycling, and improving soil health. For instance, Rhizobium sp. forms symbiotic associations with leguminous plants, facilitating nitrogen fixation and improving soil fertility (Jaiswal et al., 2021). This enhances agricultural productivity and reduces the need for synthetic fertilizers, promoting economic efficiency and sustainability. In addition, bacterial biofilm colonizing on the surface of plant roots enhances nutrient uptake, water retention, and disease resistance, leading to increased crop yields and farmer income. Pseudomonas aeruginosa, Pseudomonas oryzihabitans, Pseudomonas otitidis, Bacillus subtilis, Bacillus brevis, Bacillus cereus, Bacillus circulars, Bacillus firmus, and Bacillus licheniformis are widely used for plant growth promotion (Nagrale et al., 2023). Furthermore, in aquaculture, biofloc systems use bacterial biofilm to maintain water quality, recycle nutrients, and support the growth of fish and shrimp populations (El-Sayed, 2021). These systems promote sustainable aquaculture practices, contribute to food security, and create economic opportunities for fish farmers, aligning with SDG 8.

In the industrial sector, bacterial biofilm drive innovation and infrastructure development (SDG 9) through their applications in bioremediation, bioenergy production, and biomanufacturing processes. Thus, the bacteria biofilm aims to target 9.1. For instance, biofilm-forming bacterial consortia are employed in bioremediation technologies to degrade pollutants and detoxify contaminated environments. Dehalococcoides spp. is used in the bioremediation of chlorinated solvents, and Pseudomonas putida is engaged in the degradation of hydrocarbons in oil spills (Ruikar and Pawar, 2022). Moreover, bacterial biofilm plays a crucial role in bioenergy production, contributing to sustainable energy sources and infrastructure development (Logan et al., 2019). In the biomanufacturing sector, bacterial biofilm serves as a platform for producing value-added products, including enzymes, bio-based materials, and pharmaceuticals. Biofilm-based applications include the production of enzymes such as cellulases and amylases for industrial applications and the synthesis of biopolymers like polyhydroxyalkanoates (PHAs) for biodegradable plastics. Thus, the applications of bacterial biofilm in agriculture and industry contribute to Decent Work and Economic Growth (SDG 8) by enhancing productivity, creating employment opportunities, and promoting economic resilience. Simultaneously, these innovations drive Industry, Innovation, and Infrastructure (SDG 9) by fostering technological advancements, promoting sustainable practices, and supporting infrastructure development.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Biofilm helps in carbon sequestration and mitigating climate change: climate action (SDG 13)
ce:section.ce:para: Bacterial biofilm plays a crucial role in carbon sequestration and climate change mitigation. These bacterial communities are ubiquitous in natural environments and are involved in various processes that contribute to carbon cycling and storage, aligning with the goals of SDG 13 targeting 13.2. The bacterial biofilm aids in carbon sequestration through their role in soil carbon storage (Mandal et al., 2021). The biofilm-forming soil bacteria significantly stabilize organic carbon compounds in soil aggregates. This biofilm protects organic matter from enzyme decomposition and promotes its accumulation in soil, thus sequestering carbon over long periods. For example, the biofilm formed by Pseudomonas aeruginosa facilitates the formation of stable soil aggregates and enhances the retention of organic carbon, thereby contributing to soil carbon storage (Costa et al., 2018).

Moreover, bacterial biofilm plays a pivotal role in carbon sequestration in aquatic environments by mediating carbon flux between the water and sediments. Bacterial biofilm on the surface of marine substrates facilitates the uptake and assimilation of dissolved organic carbon (DOC), effectively removing carbon from the water column and incorporating it into microbial biomass or sedimentary organic matter (Carlson and Hansell, 2015). Moreover, biofilm promotes the precipitation of CaCO3 minerals, further enhancing carbon storage in aquatic sediments. Various marine biofilm-forming bacteria such as Bacillus cereus, Bacillus subtilis, Lysinibacillus sp., Burkholderia multivorans, and Burkholderia cepacia promote carbonate mineralization through their ureolytic activity, contributing to carbon sequestration in marine ecosystems (Zhao et al., 2021). Further, bacterial biofilm contributes to carbon sequestration in marine environments by forming and maintaining coral reefs. Coral reefs are formed by the accumulation of CaCO3 skeletons secreted by corals, which are facilitated by symbiotic biofilm-forming bacteria within coral biofilm (Bang et al., 2018). The bacteria in the family Proteobacteria, Bacteroidetes, Cyanobacteria, and Firmicutes primarily help in long-term carbon sequestration in coral reef ecosystems.

In addition to carbon sequestration, biofilm contributes to climate change mitigation by influencing greenhouse gas dynamics in various environments. Biofilm-forming methanotrophic bacteria, including Methylococcus capsulatus, Methylosinus trichosporium, and Methylocystis parvus, oxidize methane in wetland soils and aquatic sediments, reducing methane emissions to the atmosphere (Chowdhury and Dick, 2013). This biofilm contains methane-oxidizing bacteria that utilize methane as a carbon and energy source, converting it into CO2, a less potent greenhouse gas. By reducing methane emissions, methanotrophic biofilm-forming bacteria play a crucial role in mitigating climate change and reducing the atmospheric concentration of greenhouse gases. Furthermore, bacterial biofilm contributes to the cycling of other greenhouse gases, such as N2O and CO2, in various ecosystems. Nitrifying and denitrifying biofilm-forming bacteria Nitrosomonas oligotropha, Nitrosospira multiformis, and Pseudomonas denitrificans respectively, in soils and aquatic sediments regulate the production and consumption of nitrous oxide by mediating the processes of nitrification and denitrification (Zhao et al., 2022). Similarly, bacterial biofilm in agricultural systems can enhance soil carbon sequestration and reduce greenhouse gas emissions through biofilm-based composting, which promotes the decomposition of organic waste materials and the retention of carbon in soil aggregates.

In conclusion, bacterial biofilm plays a multifaceted role in carbon sequestration and climate change mitigation, contributing to the objectives of Climate Action (SDG 13). Bacterial biofilm facilitates carbon storage in soils, aquatic sediments, and marine ecosystems while reducing greenhouse gas emissions through their diverse metabolic activities and interactions with the environment. Thus, understanding and harnessing the capabilities of bacterial biofilm can contribute to developing strategies for climate change mitigation and promoting sustainable ecosystems.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Bacterial biofilm restores marine and aquatic ecosystem: life below water (SDG 14)
ce:section.ce:para: Bacterial biofilm is intricate communities of marine bacteria embedded in a matrix of EPS that adhere to surfaces underwater. This biofilm plays a significant role in restoring and maintaining marine and aquatic ecosystems, aligning with the goals of SDG 14 with the aim to fulfill the target of both 14.1 and 14.2. Bacterial biofilm contributes to the health and resilience of aquatic habitats worldwide through their diverse metabolic activities and interactions with the environment. In marine environments, biofilm thrives in different environmental settings like ports, coasts, estuaries, mangroves, coral reefs, seagrass meadows, and the open ocean, each contributing to ecological processes like nutrient cycling and sediment stabilization while facing distinct environmental challenges. The significant contribution of bacterial biofilm to marine and aquatic ecosystems is their involvement in nutrient cycling. Biofilm is a hotspot of microbial activity, facilitating the transformation and recycling of essential nutrients such as nitrogen, phosphorus, and ammonia (Chen et al., 2022). The nitrogen-fixing bacteria, including Rhizobium leguminosarum, Azotobacter spp., and Clostridium pasteurianum, produced biofilm, which helps convert atmospheric nitrogen into ammonium, used by various marine organisms (Singh et al., 2023). Similarly, denitrifying bacteria such as Pseudomonas denitrificans produced biofilm that removes excess nitrogen from the water by converting NO3 â into N2, thereby mitigating eutrophication and promoting water quality (Wang and Chu, 2016). Eutrophication occurs when excessive nutrients, particularly nitrogen and phosphorus, are present in the water bodies. Excess nutrients lead to plant growth on the water surfaces, reduced O2 levels, and altered species composition. In nutrient-rich environments, biofilm-forming nitrogen-fixing bacteria such as Azotobacter spp. increased nitrogen availability promotes algal and plant growth and exacerbates eutrophication (Pittol et al., 2016). Thus, bacterial biofilm promotes algal bloom formation by providing surfaces for algal attachment, colonization, and development.

Furthermore, bacterial biofilm plays a crucial role in bioremediation of contaminated wastewater. Bacterial biofilm is highly efficient at degrading a wide range of organic and inorganic pollutants in the wastewater discharged from domestic, industrial, and agricultural sources. The biofilm-forming aerobic and anaerobic bacteria, including Pseudomonas spp., Bacillus spp., and Mycobacterium spp. degrade organic pollutants such as petroleum hydrocarbons, pesticides, and industrial chemicals through metabolic pathways like biodegradation and mineralization (Mohapatra et al., 2022). Inorganic contaminants like heavy metals can also be immobilized and detoxified by biofilm-forming bacteria such as Bacillus subtilis, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, Alcaligenes faecalis, Marinobacter spp., and Burkholderia cepacia through processes like biosorption, bioprecipitation, biomineralization, bioaccumulation, and biotransformation (Yadav and Chandra, 2020). Several hydrocarbon-degrading bacteria, including Staphylococcus saprophyticus, Bacillus amyloliquefaciens, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Pseudomonas furukawaii formed biofilm on the surface of the oil particles and thereby break down oil spills and other petroleum-based pollutants, reducing their harmful effects on marine life (Mahto et al., 2022b). Biofilm-forming bacteria in marine environments can effectively degrade pollutants like heavy metals and hydrocarbons, aiding in marine bioremediation and environmental clean-up (Priyadarshanee and Das, 2021). A quantitative evaluation of in-situ bioremediation in the Bohai Sea, China, showed significant improvements in compound pollution, with bacteria achieving up to 68% reduction in PAHs and a 73% decrease in heavy metals after 210 days (Wang et al., 2020). Bacterial biofilm also helps in microplastic degradation by colonizing and adhering to microplastic surfaces, leading to physical and chemical degradation. For example, biofilm-forming plastic-degrading bacteria like Pseudomonas spp., Shewenella spp., Vibrio alginolyticus, Rhodococcus sp., Streptococcus nigra, and Bacillus spp. can produce enzymes that break down the polymer chains of microplastic, facilitating their degradation into smaller, less harmful fragments (Malla et al., 2023). In-situ bioremediation of Malaysian mangrove soil contaminated with PET and PS microplastic, using an indigenous microbial consortium, achieved an 18% reduction in microplastic in 90 days through biofilm formation. The process also altered soil composition, increasing Si, S, and Fe while decreasing C, O, Na, Mg, Al, Cl, and K (Auta et al., 2022).

In addition to nutrient cycling and bioremediation, bacterial biofilm contributes to the formation and maintenance of essential habitats such as coral reefs and estuarine ecosystems. Bacterial biofilm is the pioneer organisms in these habitats, providing substrate for the attachment and growth of diverse marine organisms. For example, biofilm on coral reefs facilitates the settlement of coral larvae and promotes reef accretion. The biofilm-forming bacteria such as Pseudomonas aeruginosa, Serratia macrescens, Enterobacter sp., and Pantoea dispersa also stabilize the sediment of the mangrove forest and thereby support the growth of mangrove seedlings (Rath and Dangar, 2014). Further, these biofilm-forming bacteria with plant growth-promoting traits can enhance mangrove ecosystem resilience by improving plant and soil health, aiding in nutrient cycling, stress resistance, and pollutant degradation (Panda and Das, 2024). A recent study describes the role of EPS in metal sequestration during mangrove restoration (Cheng et al., 2022). Similarly, in estuaries and seagrass meadows, biofilm-forming bacteria improve nutrient cycling and stabilize sediments (De Carvalho, 2018). Moreover, bacterial biofilm plays a symbiotic relationship with other marine organisms. For instance, marine bacteria produce biofilm on the surfaces of other marine animals, such as sponges, corals, and shellfish, which serve as a source of nutrition and protection (Wahl et al., 2012). This biofilm provides a rich source of organic matter for filter-feeding organisms and enhances the immune response of host organisms against pathogens. The bacterial biofilm is involved in carbon cycling in marine and aquatic ecosystems. Through processes such as photosynthesis and respiration, biofilm influences the flux of carbon between the atmosphere, water, and sediments. Thiobacillus ferrooxidans and Synechococcus spp. produced biofilm that fixes CO2 into organic carbon through photosynthesis, thereby supporting the growth of higher trophic levels in aquatic food webs (Nivetha et al., 2023). Thus, bacterial biofilm serves as producers and sources of organic matter in marine food webs, supporting trophic transfer and energy flow to higher trophic levels. The organic matter produced by bacterial biofilm undergoes trophic transfer through various pathways, ultimately supporting the growth and reproduction of higher organisms in aquatic ecosystems.

The bacterial biofilm also plays a critical role in decomposing organic matter and recycling nutrients in marine and aquatic ecosystems. The bacteria produced biofilm on the submerged surfaces such as rocks, sediments, and detritus, which helps to break down complex organic compounds into simpler forms through enzymatic degradation. This process releases nutrients such as nitrogen and phosphorus into the water, where primary producers and other organisms can utilize them. Furthermore, bacterial biofilm contributes to the resilience of marine and aquatic ecosystems in the face of environmental stressors such as pollution, climate change, and disease outbreaks. Biofilm provides a protective microenvironment for bacterial populations, enhancing their ability to tolerate and adapt to changing environmental conditions (Parrilli et al., 2022). Thus, bacterial biofilm plays a crucial role in restoring and maintaining marine and aquatic ecosystems, supporting the objectives of Life Below Water (SDG 14). Bacterial biofilm contributes to nutrient cycling, bioremediation, habitat formation, symbiotic relationships, carbon cycling, decomposition, and ecosystem resilience through diverse metabolic activities and environmental interactions. Understanding and harnessing the capabilities of bacterial biofilm helps to protect and sustainably manage marine and aquatic resources for future generations.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Bacterial biofilm aids in soil conservation, erosion prevention, and biodiversity preservation: life on land (SDG 15)
ce:section.ce:para: Soil is vital to terrestrial ecosystems, supporting plant growth, regulating water flow, and sustaining biodiversity. However, soil degradation, erosion, and biodiversity loss pose significant threats to land ecosystems worldwide. Bacterial biofilm plays a crucial role in soil conservation, erosion prevention, and biodiversity preservation, thereby contributing to the objectives of SDG 15. Soil conservation involves protecting and conserving soil resources to maintain productivity and ecological functions. Bacterial biofilm contributes to soil conservation through several mechanisms, including soil aggregation and nutrient cycling (Ahmad et al., 2017). Bacterial biofilm produces EPS, which binds soil particles together, forming stable aggregates (Costa et al., 2018). These aggregates improve soil structure, water infiltration, and nutrient retention, reducing erosion, surface runoff, and loss of topsoil. The biofilm-forming bacteria, including Bacillus cereus, Bacillus subtilis, Bacillus amylolequifaciens, Alcaligenes faecalis, and Pseudomonas aeruginosa, helps to aggregate soil particles, thereby preventing soil erosion and promoting soil stabilization (Deka et al., 2019). Moreover, bacterial biofilm helps in nutrient cycling within the soil ecosystem. They decompose organic matter, fix atmospheric nitrogen, and mineralize nutrients, making them available to plants and other organisms. For instance, biofilm-forming nitrogen-fixing bacteria such as Rhizobium leguminosarum form symbiotic associations with leguminous plants, enhancing nitrogen availability in the soil and promoting plant growth (Goyal et al., 2021). Thus, the biofilm-forming bacteria play critical roles in nutrient cycling, decomposition, and soil health.

Soil erosion is a widespread problem that leads to the loss of fertile topsoil, decreased soil productivity, and degradation of ecosystems. Bacterial biofilm contributes to erosion prevention by forming biofilm mat formation, root adherence, and biopolymer production. The bacterial biofilm forms cohesive mats or crusts on the soil surface as physical barriers to wind and water erosion. These biofilm mats stabilize the soil particles and reduce the impact of erosive forces, protecting the soil from erosion. Bacillus subtilis and Sporosarcina pasteurii produced biofilm on arid soils, preventing wind erosion and desertification (Chen et al., 2021a,b,c; Fattahi et al., 2021). Bacterial biofilm thus adheres to the surface of plant roots and forms a protective layer around them, stabilizing the soil and preventing root damage from erosion. This symbiotic relationship between plants and biofilm enhances soil stability and reduces the soil erosion risk. Pseudomonas aeruginosa colonizes around plant roots and improves plant growth (Gupta et al., 2020). In addition, it helps to increase soil aggregation and stability, thereby reducing erosion in agricultural and natural ecosystems. Moreover, biofilm-forming bacteria produced biopolymers such as exopolysaccharides and PHAs, which bind soil particles together and enhance soil stability (Reddy et al., 2022). Thus, these biopolymers improve soil structure, reduce surface runoff, and prevent soil erosion. Bacterial biofilm contributes to biodiversity preservation in terrestrial ecosystems. Hence, bacterial biofilm helps in soil conservation, erosion prevention, and biodiversity preservation in terrestrial ecosystems. Bacterial biofilm contributes to the sustainable management and conservation of land resources by promoting soil stability, reducing erosion, and enhancing biodiversity, aligning with the objectives of Life on Land SDG 15, achieving target 15.3.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Gaps, challenges, and opportunities
ce:section.ce:para: The sustainable approach involving bacterial biofilm has been a promising strategy for the remediation and ecorestoration of stressed environments. However, despite having a wide range of advantageous and imperative applications, their real-time use is circumscribed due to various factors. The inefficacy of biofilm-mediated bioremediation in alleviating environmental stress can be attributed to several reasons. Low abundance of indigenous biofilm-forming bacterial populations, inadequate nutrient availability, and reduced bioavailability of pollutants to bacteria often retards the bioremediation efficiency. Biological mechanisms governing the remediation process might be affected by fluctuations in abiotic parameters such as salinity, pH, and temperature, which further leads to decelerated biofilm formation, reduced metal binding potential, and Na+ uptake (Bhatt et al., 2020). Indeed, the biofilm-assisted bioremediation rate is slow compared to conventional chemical treatment methods. Degradation of recalcitrant compounds by bacterial biofilm often produces harmful metabolic products, further contaminating the environment, making this biological approach suitable for modest pollutant loads and cases where immediate recovery is unnecessary (Sharma et al., 2020). Due to the coexistence of numerous heavy metals and metal-metal interactions taking place among them, the efficiency of metal carbonate precipitation mediated by biofilm may be impacted (Chen et al., 2021a,b,c). Restoring marine environments with biofilm technology faces several challenges. The complexity and variability of marine ecosystems, such as fluctuating temperatures, salinity, fluid velocity, and viscosity of marine water, and turbulence created by organic matter can impact biofilm stability and effectiveness (Sonawane et al., 2022).

Biofilm of rapidly proliferating bacteria cannot be used in remediation by biofilm reactors due to their low machine stability and reactor capacity dependence on dispersed O2 (Mitra and Mukhopadhyay, 2016). Despite several limitations in a real-time application, bacterial biofilm is still considered a potential elicitor for eco-restoration due to its cost-effectiveness and a higher degree of sustainability. Several studies are continuously being conducted to design appropriate modules for improved biofilm-forming strains. An innovative method of bioremediation has been formulated, which uses DNA-harbouring catabolic genes in biofilm to mimic natural processes of transformation that promote the biodegradation of specific contaminants. The biodegradation process can be further enhanced by the horizontal transfer of potent pollutant biodegrading genes from genetically modified bacteria to biofilm-forming bacterial populations. However, there is a lot of debate and disagreement about the release and application of genetically engineered microorganisms (GEMs) in nature; hence, their commercialization is a challenge, and the assessment of potential risks associated with the use of genetically modified organisms (GMOs) in field application should be considered (Saxena et al., 2020). Cell-to-cell interactions and QS might play a vital role in governing the degradation potential of bacterial biofilm, and further investigation is needed (Yadav and Chandra, 2020). Genetic to metabolite multi-omics techniques offer a comprehensive understanding of biofilm biology, including studying transcriptomes, proteomes, and metabolites, which also investigate the mechanisms behind biofilm traits. A multitude of data regarding biofilm resistance, phenotypic variations between planktonic and biofilm cells, interactions between biofilm and recalcitrant, and other biological alterations taking place in a biofilm system would be available through omics techniques (Mishra et al., 2022). Therefore, biofilm research is an emerging field of study in sustainable development that could offer additional metabolic power for biological remediation technologies and examine the survival methods of bacteria.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Conclusion
ce:section.ce:para: Biofilm and their EPS matrix play a crucial role in enhancing bacterial adaptability and resilience towards various environmental pollutants. The intricate interaction between TCS, QS and c-di-GMP signaling molecules governs the biofilm development, which also provides protection against external stressors, ensuring their survival under adverse conditions. These unique biofilm features render it a suitable mode for carrying out degradation process, positioning bacterial biofilm applications as a sustainable approach for environmental remediation. Biofilm-forming bacteria employ variable remediation mechanisms, which offer significant benefits in enhancing the soil, air, and water quality. Bacterial exopolysaccharides contain negatively charged functional groups which interact with the ions, heavy metals, and toxic soil aggregates, leading to their entrapment and removal, thereby facilitating soil restoration. Moreover, establishing bacterial biofilm as biofilters in bioreactors sequesters the air pollutants (VOCs, NOx, and SOx), followed by their degradation. While hydrophobic VOCs are removed by biosorption, other gaseous pollutants are mitigated by chemical oxidation or reduction process. Additionally, enzymes from biofilm metabolize the complex organic pollutants such as hydrocarbons, oil spills, and microplastic present in the wastewater, thus supporting aquatic ecosystem health. Biofilm-based bioreactors effectively treat industrial and domestic wastewater by undergoing various aerobic and anaerobic fermentations. Biofilm, as a mode of growth, provides a wide range of applications in biodiversity conservation and environmental clean-up. Therefore, bacterial biofilm emerges as a promising strategy for addressing different goals of SDGs. Further research and field-based studies are necessary to understand and optimize the commercial viability of biofilm-based interventions for widespread application in ecosystem restoration initiatives.
